title: Kemp issues state of emergency ahead of Tropical Storm Debby
message:
AUGUSTA, Ga. (WRDW/WAGT) - Ahead of Tropical Storm Debby’s possibly historic flooding, officials in South Carolina reached out to dam owners across the state.
More than 50 dams across South Carolina were breached during the 1,000-year flood.
South Carolina leaders worry Debby could cause similar destruction this week.
They are asking dam owners to prepare now by:Clearing debris from spillways.
Staff members with the South Carolina Department of Environmental Services are performing pre-storm assessments at high-hazard dams.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Debby's potentially historic flooding in South Carolina has state officials reaching out to dam owners to prepare by clearing debris from spillways. Staff with the South Carolina Department of Environmental Services are conducting pre-storm assessments at high-hazard dams, and have identified 50 dams that breached in 2016's 1,000-year flood and warn Debby could cause similar destruction this week.

title: Five dead as Tropical Storm Debby soaks south - eastern US
message:
At least five people have been killed after Hurricane Debby slammed into Florida before weakening to a tropical storm.
The National Hurricane Center warned of a "life-threatening" flood threat as the "slow-moving storm" drops "torrential rains".
Debby made landfall on Monday morning as a category one hurricane in the Big Bend region of Florida's Gulf Coast.
The slow-moving pace of the storm could bring “catastrophic flooding”, Jamie Rhome, the deputy director of the hurricane centre, said.
Before the storm made landfall, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency for 61 of Florida's 67 counties.

title: Tropical Storm Debby : Tropical storm Debby ravages Florida and Georgia : Many dead , cities flooded , thousands left without power
message:
Key developments:Casualties:Rescues and evacuations:Flooding threat:Power outages:State of emergency:Flight cancellations:Charleston curfew:Government response:Continued threat:Historical context:Uncertainty ahead:As Tropical Storm Debby continues to wreak havoc across the southeastern United States, the storm has brought unprecedented rainfall, deadly winds, and widespread flooding .
The storm, which made landfall in Florida as a Category 1 hurricane, has already resulted in multiple deaths, mass evacuations, and significant damage across Florida, Georgia , and the Carolinas.Authorities are racing against time to rescue residents from flooded homes, particularly in Sarasota, Florida, and Manatee County, where hundreds have been rescued.
The storm's path has brought it into Georgia and is expected to stall, bringing even more rainfall and potential catastrophic flooding to the region.The storm has since weakened to a tropical storm but continues to pose a significant threat, particularly to low-lying areas along the Eastern seaboard.
In Florida, a 13-year-old boy died when a tree fell on a mobile home.
Additionally, a truck driver was killed in Tampa after losing control of his vehicle in the storm.Approximately 500 people were rescued from flooded homes in Sarasota, while 186 were saved in nearby Manatee County.

title: US Border Patrol : Hurricane Debby unexpected find : $1 million in cocaine found on Florida beach amidst hurricane aftermath
message:
Hurricane Debby that made landfall on Florida on Monday, not only brought high winds and torrential rain but also an unexpected discovery- 25 tightly sealed packages of cocaine worth over a staggering $1 million.
"Hurricane Debby blew 25 packages of cocaine (70 lbs.)
onto a beach in the Florida Keys," US Border Patrol acting chief patrol Agent Samuel Briggs II wrote on X.The valuable stash, which Briggs estimated at over $1 million, was found by a concerned citizen who contacted the authorities, as reported by AFP.This isn't the first time such an incident has occurred.
In July 2023, the mayor of Tampa, Florida, similarly stumbled upon 70 pounds (31.7 kilograms) of cocaine that had washed ashore in the Florida Keys during a vacation.Debby struck Florida's northern Big Bend region as a Category One hurricane before weakening to a tropical storm.
As the storm's effects were felt across the state, with the cocaine washing up along the southernmost shores of the Florida Keys.In addition to bringing cocaine, Debby has killed one person, knocked out power for hundreds of thousands of people, and could produce life-threatening storm surges as well as catastrophic flooding.The Florida Keys, a chain of islands extending from the southern tip of the state, are situated near several Caribbean nations that are key transit points for cocaine trafficking from South America to Europe and North America, including into Florida.

Debby is forecast to eventually drift off the coast into the warm Atlantic waters off the Georgia and South Carolina coastlines, where she should maintain tropical storm intensity.
Will Debby impact the DC region?
While Debby will remain far from the D.C. region during the middle of the week, the moisture she is propelling atmospherically will drift northward ahead of the storm.

title: How did Debby surge in Tampa Bay compare to previous storms ?
message:
Tampa Bay escaped Hurricane Debby without suffering surge flooding as harsh as other recent storms, data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association shows.
In Tampa Bay, water levels at the region’s tidal gauge stations were elevated Monday, combining with excessive rainfall to cause severe flooding throughout low-lying neighborhoods, including Shore Acres and Riviera Bay.
But the storm surge was less severe than recent storms, including an unnamed December 2023 storm that never reached hurricane strength.
At points of high tide, water levels around Tampa Bay reached about 3 feet above the average height of the highest tide recorded each day.

title: Debby impact on Florida and Georgia shows another example of the growing trend in destructive , stalling hurricanes
message:
Debby yet another example of slow-moving or stalling hurricanes, part of a growing trendHurricane Debby made landfall as a Category 1 storm near Steinhatchee, Florida, early Monday morning.
Debby is another example of a tropical storm or hurricane that slowed down or stalled after landfall.
Three other notable storms that did the same were hurricanes Harvey in 2017, Florence in 2018, and Dorian in 2019.
Seeing tropical storms or hurricanes "slow down" is not a new phenomenon.
Because tropical storms and hurricanes are large weather systems, it takes longer for them to fizzle out finally.

title: First Alert Weather In - Depth : Flooding is the greatest threat from Hurricane Debby

We know that Debby came ashore as a category one storm with winds near 80 miles per hour.
The strong winds will certainly cause power outages, but a bigger concern with this hurricane is the amount of freshwater flooding.
Doppler radar estimates show this heavy rain caused extensive flooding from the north and south of the City of Tampa.
We hope this does not come to fruition, but this could be some of the worst flooding since Hurricane Florence back in 2018.

title: What Is Hurricane Storm Surge , And Why Can It Be So Catastrophic ?
message:
Depending on the size and track of the hurricane, storm surge flooding can last for several hours.
With powerful waves on top of it, a hurricane's storm surge can cause catastrophic damage.
Hurricane Ike's 15- to 17-foot storm surge and waves swept hundreds of homes off Texas' Bolivar Peninsula in 2008.
Other factors that shape storm surgeOcean tides – caused by the gravity of the moon and sun – can also strengthen or weaken the impact of storm surge.
When a hurricane arrives, the higher ocean means storm surge can bring water further inland, to a more dangerous and widespread effect.

title: Tropical Storm Debby leaves thousands of Valdosta residents without power
message:
VALDOSTA, Ga. (WALB) - The winds and downpours from Tropical Storm Debby put some people right back where they were during Hurricane Idalia — with no power.
Georgia Power reports in the southwest region alone, 14,500 people are without power with 12,000 of those people in Lowndes County.
(walb)Joe Brownlee, a Georgia Power Southwest Region executive, said the difference between Hurricane Idalia and Hurricane Debby is that damage and power outages are more scattered.
Power crews also fear with Hurricane Debby lingering, there may be more impacts.
Georgia Power said it may take three days to get everyone’s power restored.

As of early morning on Tuesday, most tornadoes warnings placed by the National Weather Service in Atlanta and Charleston have expired. None have thus far been confirmed in the county.
The National Weather Service has issued the first ever flash flood emergency warning for Beaufort County.

Overnight, over 10,000 customers in Beaufort County lost power.
As of Tuesday morning, Duke Energy encourages people to report power outages on its website or through its app. In a tweet, the company encourages customers to take a photo and indicate exactly the area where the power outage occurred.

title: $1m of cocaine blown onto Florida Keys by  catastrophic  Storm Debby
message:

Twenty five packages washed up on a beach and were reported to police by a “good Samaritan”, said Samuel Briggs, the acting chief patrol agent.
He did not give the location for the discovery but shared an image of the haul on X, which showed 25 bricks covered in a black rectangular sticker with a red triangular symbol on it.
The storm drenched Florida on Monday, killing at least five people and threatening south-eastern US states with heavy rainfall and catastrophic flooding.

Northern Florida, the coastal regions of Georgia and South Carolina and parts of North Carolina are bracing for severe rain and catastrophic flooding this week as the Debby storm system moves up and east.
But experts say the worst is yet to come as the storm system is expected to stall over the Southeast region.
More than 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain was recorded in South Carolina after that storm hit the Carolinas.
Northern Florida as well as low-lying areas including Savannah, Georgia, and Hilton Head Island and Charleston, South Carolina, are expected to see the most severe flooding.
Jeffrey Collins contributed from Columbia, South Carolina.
event_breakdown: Natural disasters such as the Northern Florida as well as low-lying areas including Savannah, Georgia, and Hilton Head Island and Charleston, South Carolina, are expected to see the most severe flooding.

title: Tropical Storm Debby expected to send flooding to the Southeast
message:
Northern Florida, the coastal regions of Georgia and South Carolina and parts of North Carolina are bracing for severe rain and catastrophic flooding this week as the Debby storm system moves up and east.
But experts say the worst is yet to come as the storm system is expected to stall over the Southeast region.
More than 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain was recorded in South Carolina after that storm hit the Carolinas.
Northern Florida as well as low-lying areas including Savannah, Georgia, and Hilton Head Island and Charleston, South Carolina, are expected to see the most severe flooding.
Jeffrey Collins contributed from Columbia, South Carolina.
event_breakdown:
Storm to Bring Major Rains, Severe Flooding to Southeastern States

A slow-moving storm system is expected to dump as much as 2 feet of rain through early next week across the Southeast, causing what the National Weather Service calls "unprecedented and historic" severe flooding in nine states, with dozens of roads already overtopping their banks.

The worst of the flooding, meteorologists said, is likely to begin Sunday and last until Wednesday.

The National Weather Service reported flood warnings Saturday across much of South Carolina, including the Columbia and Florence areas. Rivers at or near flood stage include Merservey River at Columbia, Congaree River at Columbia and Cheraw, Lynches River near Bennettsville, Saluda River near Columbia, lower Edisto River near Peak, Santee River at Manning, and Turbeese Creek near Georgetown.

Even on the coast, more than 23 inches of rain have been recorded in Georgetown, on the north-central South Carolina coast, since Tuesday, according to the National Weather Service.

Flood warnings were also in effect for parts of Georgia, North Carolina, Virginia, Maryland, Delaware, Tennessee and Kentucky on Saturday.

The heaviest rain was expected to fall between the Carolinas and Atlanta through Saturday, with several inches also possible in Tennessee, Louisiana and parts of the Southeast through Wednesday.

title: At least four dead , 300 , 000 without power as Tropical Storm Debby hits Florida
message:
At least four deaths have been confirmed as a result of Hurricane Debby, which made landfall today on Florida’s Big Bend at 7 a.m.
The National Hurricane Center said that Debby was downgraded at 11 a.m. on Monday to a tropical storm, but its affects still continue to ravage the state as it moves inland with flooding rain, damaging winds and a life-threatening storm surge.
Debby, which made landfall as a Category 1 storm, touched down near Steinhatchee about 7 a.m.
After landfall, power outages skyrocketed to more than 300,000 utility customers in the Sunshine State, according to PowerOutage.us.
Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency for 61 counties expected to be affected by the storm.
event_breakdown: Hurricane Debby made landfall on Florida's Big Bend at 7 a.m. today and is wreaking havoc on Florida with flooding rain, damaging winds and life-threatening storm surge.

title: Tropical Storm Debby Dumps Flooding Rains As It Inches Up Atlantic Coast
message:
Tropical Storm Debby has moved into the Southeast U.S., bringing torrential downpours and flooding.
The storm, which made landfall on the Gulf Coast of Florida as a Category 1 hurricane, has already claimed at least five lives and caused flash flooding in historic Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina.
Despite being downgraded to a tropical storm with wind speeds near 45 mph, meteorologists warn that the storm's rainfall capacity makes it extremely dangerous.
Debby is expected to produce potentially historic rainfall totals of 10 to 20 inches, with maximum amounts of 25 inches, bringing areas of catastrophic flooding across portions of southeast Georgia, the eastern half of South Carolina, and southeast North Carolina through Friday.
Charleston, South Carolina, is particularly vulnerable due to its geography.
event_breakdown:

It is expected to produce potentially historic rainfall totals of 10 to 20 inches, with maximum amounts of 25 inches, bringing areas of catastrophic flooding across portions of southeast Georgia, the eastern half of South Carolina, and southeast North Carolina through Friday. 

The deaths, which include two drownings, occurred in Panama City, a Florida Panhandle city where nearly 1,000 homes were destroyed in 2005 by Hurricane Michael, a Category 3 storm.

title: Tropical Storm Debby in Florida : What Travelers Need to Know
message:
Tropical Storm Debby made landfall in Florida as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday morning—causing wide-scale power outages, catastrophic flooding, and dangerous storm surges throughout the Big Bend region on the Gulf Coast.
It has since been downgraded to a tropical storm.
At least five people have died across Florida and Georgia, with hundreds more rescued from their flooded homes.
“While Hurricane Debby is forecasted to be a slow-moving storm impacting the north of Florida, travel disruptions are being felt all over the state," Michael Holtz, CEO and founder of luxury travel agency SmartFlyer, tells Condé Nast Traveler.
Here's what travelers should know as Tropical Storm Debby in Florida makes its way up the southeastern seaboard.

event_breakdown:
Hurricane Ida
On August 29, 2021, Hurricane Ida made landfall in Louisiana as a strong Category 4 hurricane. The storm brought sustained winds of up to 150 miles per hour (240 km/h) and heavy rain, prompting a state of emergency to be declared in Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida. At least one person was reported dead after the storm made landfall.

Hurricane Ida caused widespread power outages, destroying buildings and causing damage across a wide area. As the storm moved northeast, it brought heavy rain to parts of Mississippi, Alabama, and Tennessee, causing flooding in some areas.

Hurricane Ida weakened into a tropical storm as it moved over land, but it regained strength over the Atlantic Ocean and regained hurricane status on August 30. The storm is expected to make landfall in the Northeast United States on August 31, bringing heavy rain and gusty winds to the region.

title: At least four dead , 300 , 000 without power as Tropical Storm Debby hits Florida
message:
At least four deaths have been confirmed as a result of Hurricane Debby, which made landfall today on Florida’s Big Bend at 7 a.m.
The National Hurricane Center said that Debby was downgraded at 11 a.m. on Monday to a tropical storm, but its affects still continue to ravage the state as it moves inland with flooding rain, damaging winds and a life-threatening storm surge.
Debby, which made landfall as a Category 1 storm, touched down near Steinhatchee about 7 a.m.
After landfall, power outages skyrocketed to more than 300,000 utility customers in the Sunshine State, according to PowerOutage.us.
Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency for 61 counties expected to be affected by the storm.
event_breakdown: Hurricane Debby made landfall near Steinhatchee on Monday, leaving a trail of destruction in its wake. The storm downed power lines and caused widespread power outages, prompting the governor to declare a state of emergency for 61 affected counties. As of Tuesday morning, more than 300,000 utility customers were still without power.

title: Tropical Storm Debby Dumps Flooding Rains As It Inches Up Atlantic Coast
message:
Tropical Storm Debby has moved into the Southeast U.S., bringing torrential downpours and flooding.
The storm, which made landfall on the Gulf Coast of Florida as a Category 1 hurricane, has already claimed at least five lives and caused flash flooding in historic Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina.
Despite being downgraded to a tropical storm with wind speeds near 45 mph, meteorologists warn that the storm's rainfall capacity makes it extremely dangerous.
Debby is expected to produce potentially historic rainfall totals of 10 to 20 inches, with maximum amounts of 25 inches, bringing areas of catastrophic flooding across portions of southeast Georgia, the eastern half of South Carolina, and southeast North Carolina through Friday.
Charleston, South Carolina, is particularly vulnerable due to its geography.

title: McMaster gives damage assessment after Tropical Storm Debby swamps South Carolina
message:
As Tropical Storm Debby continues to hover along the South Carolina coast, flooding and at least one tornado have ensued, according to state officials.
Henry McMaster and other state officials gave an update Tuesday on conditions in South Carolina after Tropical Storm Debby hit the coast Monday evening.
Despite damage along the state’s coastline, including from a tornado in Edisto Beach, no injuries or fatalities have so far been reported, McMaster said.
“We have not had any reports of any fatalities, and we hope that it stays like that,” McMaster said.
Among the strongest winds were 63 mph at Folly Beach, 59 mph at Battery Point in Charleston County, and 56 mph at Isle of Palms.

title: Catfish appear on flooded streets in Pinellas Park
message:
Catfish washed up in various residential areas of western Florida as Tropical Storm Debby caused flooding on Sunday before making landfall as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday morning.
In Pinellas Park, Joanna Mack and her husband, Stan, spotted at least two catfish struggling to swim down a partially flooded road.
They used shovels and fishing rods to help push the fish toward storm drains and into deeper water.

title: Gov . Moore signs State of Preparedness Declaration ahead of possible arrival of Debby
message:
Wes Moore signed a State of Preparedness declaration ahead of possible effects from Hurricane Debby this week.
Maryland could experience heavy rain and winds, inland and tidal flooding, according to the Office of the Governor.
By declaring a State of Preparedness, I am directing the Department of Emergency Management to coordinate the comprehensive preparation of State government ahead of potential impacts from the remnants of Tropical Storm Debby,” said Gov.
“Residents and visitors should monitor local weather forecasts, remain vigilant, and be prepared to follow safety instructions from local emergency officials.”Gov.
Moore signed an executive order creating the State of Preparedness last November.
